title: regarding jon snow’s knee bending
body:
personally i would have no problem with jon swearing fealty to House Targaryen if the show had presented it more then just “love sick puppy gives up for nothing” as it appeared to be. 

rather if Jon and Daenerys had, were she amenable to the idea, worked out an agreement that he would bend the knee AFTER the dead were defeated or that he would bend the knee in exchange for her troops and dragons heading north to fight with him, it would be far less of a problem. 

both scenarios are in my mind, fair; jon will give Daenerys what she wants(a loyal Northern vassal) and Daenerys will help destroy the army of the dead since the north cannot do it alone. 

but hey what do I know

summary: It pisses me off when people say Dany didn't care that Viserion died, she was obviously in shock when he died, and she was also...
question: It pisses me off when people say Dany didn't care that Viserion died, she was obviously in shock when he died, and she was also very clearly horrified and distraught as well, just because someone doesn't burst into tears, doesn't mean their not sad...
answer:
Here’s Jon after Rickon was killed right in front of him:

Looks a bit familiar right? It’s shock. Or in Dany’s case it’s expected to be like a woman thing where she has to scream and faint? I don’t even feel like expanding on this further. I’ve just come to the expectation that some in this fandom reserve this kind of hypocrisy for Dany and only Dany. Not Jon, not Stannis, not Robb, not even Cersei. But Daenerys.

blog.name: conecteseatimesmo
blog.title: Conecte-se a ti Mesmo
blog.description:
A cultura POP possui o incrível poder de conseguir despertar o interesse nas massas, possuir legiões de fãs e também, ensinar história! 

Sim, é possível aprender alguns elementos históricos so observando detalhes as vezes nem tão pequenos em livros, filmes, séries e até musicas de grande sucesso. 

O principal objetivo deste blog é este, buscar e explicar tais elementos.

summary: GAME OF THRONES  Game of thrones é uma saga de livros e uma das séries de TV de mais sucesso de todos os tempos. Não é segredo...
caption:
GAME OF THRONES

Game of thrones é uma saga de livros e uma das séries de TV de mais sucesso de todos os tempos. Não é segredo que o autor G. R. R. Martin usou da cultura e história medieval como um dos maiores meios de inspiração. Aqui vamos colocar as principais e mais marcantes. Como na idade média, Game of Thrones é extremamente brutal e mostra como os conflitos regiam a sociedade. A idade média era considerada, pelo poeta Francesco Petrarca, um buraco negro entre a antiguidade e o seu próprio tempo. Porém no século XIX foi vista como uma era de ouro para os artistas do romantismo, nomes coo Walter Scott e Richard Wagner comprovam isto. Este último por exemplo, foi uma das inspirações para Tolkien criar senhor dos anéis. As crônicas de Gelo e Fogo entra nesta de fantasia medieval.

A guerra pelo trono, das casas Stark e Lannister é uma referência clara a Guerra das Rosas, que aconteceu em 1455 e durou 30 anos na Inglaterra, entre as famílias York e Lancaster (se observar bem, até os nomes são parecidos). Logo no início da série, Ned Stark leva seu filho mais novo, Bran, para ver um desertor ser decapitado, queria que ele já se acostumasse com isto, a negligência e a inexistência da infância é outra característica muito marcante, as crianças normalmente já começavam a labuta por volta dos 10 anos.

O incesto fortemente praticado pela família Targaryen e por Jaime e Cersei Lannister foi muito repudiado e causou estranheza em quem visse a série, mas também era muito comum dentre as famílias de nobres, eles priorizavam se casar apenas com realeza, por ser uma cartada diplomática e manter o sangue, algumas monarquias levaram isto as últimas consequências.

As técnicas de batalhas adotadas possuem grandes ligações, por exemplo, a batalha dos bastardos que acontecem no final da sexta temporada, o exército de Jon Snow estava prestes a ser engolido pelo de Ramsey, cercado pelos escudos e pelas lanças, e era exatamente o mesmo método que os Romanos usavam para conseguir vencer os bárbaros mesmo que estes estejam em maior número. Como aconteceu na Batalha de Watling Street, em 61, 10 mil romanos venceram 230 mil celtas icenos.

Em 126 foi construída a Muralha de Adriano pelos romanos, com o intuito de separar o mundo civilizado contra os bárbaros do norte, essa forte tensão é um dos marcos para a transição para a Idade Média. No livro de George Martin, existe uma muralha de gelo que separa o mundo dos reinos e das casas do mundo dos selvagens, protegido pela guarda da noite, ao norte da muralha habitavam os selvagens, povo sem reino e que não compartilhava da mesma religião que os demais ao sul.

Até mesmo uma das cenas mais sangrentas da série, que é o casamento vermelho teve sua inspiração em coisas que já aconteceram, assim como Robb Stark, Eduardo da casa York resolveu se casar por segredo, falando que era por amor, o que causou revolta em seus aliados na guerra das rosas. Em 1440 na Escócia aconteceu o Jantar Negro, o rei havia morrido e seu filho de 10 anos tomou o poder, o que gerou disputa entre famílias poderosas, o clã Douglas se tornou o guardião oficial, o que fez com que outras duas famílias tramassem o assassinato dele, como Walder Frey e Roose Bolton, essas duas famílias chamaram as Douglas para um jantar e serviu cabeça de touro negro, o que representava a morte, e então, todos os Douglas foram assassinados sob a acusação que eles haviam traído a Escócia.

O grande septão e toda força religiosa que passou a existir em Porto Real pela fé militante é uma clara analogia da força católica e a inquisição que existiu na idade média, eles pedem a confissão dos pecados para que a pessoa possa se redimir, além de impor castigos e julgamentos para aqueles que consideram pecadores, crimes como sodomia que era fortemente julgado e condenado na idade média é retratado na série. O próprio autor disse para a revista Entertainment Weekly que “A fé militante é a minha versão da Igreja católica medieval, com um toque de fantasia (…) em vez da trindade católica você tem os sete – um deus com sete aspectos. No Catolicismo, são três aspectos: Pai. Filho e Espírito Santo.”

A religião zoroastrismo também é inspiração para a religião que a Melisandre prega, possuía como seu principal elemento o fogo e é a religião monoteísta mais antiga do mundo, que deu origem a outras como o judaísmo e o cristianismo, ela possuía a crença no dualismo, paraíso e a ressurreição do messias. Embora explore também elementos como o fantástico medieval, como dragões, os White walkers que são referências um certo tipo de fadas celtas, o corvo de três olhos e muito mais, muitos momentos e acontecimentos se assemelham a realidade, principalmente a personalidade dos personagens e o caráter violento da série que era característica da época.

summary: “There is only one war that matters…the Great War, and it is here”
caption: “There is only one war that matters…the Great War, and it is here”

blog.name: noordinarylines

blog.description: *Extraordinary things are always hiding in places people never think to look*

tags: random sentences put together makes a drabble
just because i felt like it
title: Random Sentences Put Together
body:
He could feel himself slowly fading from his own mind as he sat alone at the edge of the cliff and cried for the boy that never existed at all. He had lost his sense of light and knew he would not make it home tonight. As his feet dangled on the cliff, he could feel the wind and hear the waves. In that moment he saw eternity and was driven mad. 

He was sentenced to die. He had finally come to terms with his death, and he was ready to let go. He didn’t even know her name, yet he felt sorry for her - for the pain that she was going to live through. He knew there was no greater terror than watching something you love fall apart in front of your eyes.

summary: Writer's Guide to Characters: Traits and Personality
body:
Writer’s Guide to Characters: Traits and Personality

Now your character has a shell, memories, thoughts and opinions. Now onto the character of your character to explore what kind of person your character is.


Traits

Traits are like a coin, you can come up heads or tails: good and bad. Everyone has good traits and bad.

  • Good Traits: Loyalty, Bravery, Kindness, cleverness, Strength, Courage, politeness, Honour
  • Bad Traits: Greedy, Vain, cruel, Anger, Vindictiveness, Spitefulness, Impulsive, rude, arrogant

Characters need both good and bad. No person is wholly good or evil.


Reasons why

No character is simply kind because they are. No character is spiteful without reason. Characters are clay, moulded by experience. Explore a character’s background and pinpoint certain events that give your character reason to be. In ASOIAF, we can see Sansa/Alayne becoming witty and sarcastic in the Alayne sample chapter in Winds of Winter after a few months under Littlefinger’s wing. In PJO, Luke Castellan becomes bitter and resentful after a failed quest, turning him against Olympus and his dad.


Traits = Motives

Personal traits are the death of straightforwardness. Characters may reject a plain and simple path because they are too loyal, too impulsive, too spiteful and too polite. Harry is too loyal and far too brave. He puts himself in danger to save people even when a safer option is there. Use traits as roadblocks for a character to bump into and then eventually crawl over. Good traits may be the downfall of a character. Ned Stark was too honourable. Bad traits sometimes help a character. Littlefinger is a liar and a betrayer and yet he is still alive in ASOIAF.

blog.name: tatticstudio55
blog.title: pro jonerys who likes healthy debates

title: Sodom and Gomorrah
body:
We can draw many parallels between the doom of Valyria and the destruction of Sodom. Moreover, we might also take bits and pieces of the myth to predict how asoiaf/got might end.

“In the Genesis account, God reveals to Abraham that Sodom and Gomorrah are to be destroyed for their grave sins (18:20). Abraham pleads for the lives of any righteous people living there, especially the lives of his nephew, Lot, and his family. God agrees to spare the cities if 10 righteous people can be found (18:23–32). Two angels are sent to Lot in Sodom but are met with a wicked mob who are then struck blind by the angelic guests (19:1–11). Finding only Lot and his family as righteous among the inhabitants, the angels warn Lot to quickly evacuate the city and to not look back. As they flee the destruction, Lot’s wife looks back upon the city and is turned into a pillar of salt (19:12–29).” (Source here)

To add some context (and details…), the city of Sodom was destroyed in a rain of fire and sulfur. The original “sin” of the inhabitants, except Lot and his family, would’ve been to deny hospitality to the 2 angels (disguised as men), then request of Lot to break guest rights by giving them the guests under his roof &protection. The men of Sodom apparently would’ve tried to break inside Lot’s house, then, only to be struck blind by the two angels.

Let’s remember two elements here: the punishment of Sodom, and the punishment of Lot’s wife.

Valyria is destroyed by fire and sulphur (from volcanic eruptions), counting only a handful of survivors (the Targaryen) who fled in time (like Lot and his family), and although we don’t really know why, or what caused the Doom, it’s almost 100% sure that the causes weren’t entirely “natural”. Sodom was destroyed because its inhabitants had angered God, and the reason why Valyria was destroyed probably isn’t so different: the valyrian and their dragonlords had angered the gods, somehow. Not necessarily because of their “depravities”, but rather because (and this is where I throw my first speculation) they mingled too much with forces not meant to be possessed and controlled by humans: blood magic, denaturing magical experiments, spells to bind dragons to their wills.

I use the term “gods” with a grain of salt: think “surnatural”, “mystical”, “surhuman”, “grander than men”. As a rule, in (all confounded) mythologies, men are neither supposed to defy gods (Prometheus, Icarus), nor can they look directly at gods, or god’s works in the making (Orpheus, Psyche, Lot’s wife). The fact that the ruins of Valyria are now oozing with “stone men” hence might have something to do with the “punishment” inflicted upon the lands: Lot’s wife was turned into a salt statue for looking back, and the “stone men” are something of statues themselves.  

Now flash forward to Westeros and their own upcoming doom: White Walkers.

Is it different from the situation in Valyria? Not really. The WW were also created as a response to men who were angering gods (cutting weirwood trees, waging war with the children of the forest, who probably personify the sacral aspect of nature). Dany’s vision of a woman, violated by 5 men/beasts all at once, in the HOTU, and the subsequent vision of the Red Wedding, with dead people, blood, limbs and heaps of food all piled up, all depict forms of “depravities” for which Sodom and Gomorrah were destroyed: rape and bestiality, gluttony, the breaking of guest rights. Cutting weirwood trees was profane in more ways than one: the red sap bleeding from the weirwood’s eyes act as a reminder to men not to look at gods directly. The Wall itself is an act of defiance against gods (humans shielding themselves from, and demonizing a more mystical, wild, archaic side of nature), and completely denatured the lands of Westeros (in “Clocks and dragons”, I argued that the Wall itself was causing the seasonal disbalance in Westeros). If the destruction of the Wall seemed nothing short of apocalyptic, it’s because it was: you’ve got gods-like figures (a dragon, an immortal man) coming in a “divine” rage for whoever dared to defy them. Theoretically speaking, men shouldn’t be able to fight that, let alone win. There lies the whole moral of the “leave to the gods what belongs to the gods” myths.

What does that say about the prospect of reinstituting peace in Westeros? At this point, that it’s unlikely.

What does it say about the (potential) fate of main characters? That’s another story. We’ll remember that not everyone was killed in the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah.

Jon: is obviously the messiah figure here (I’ve done a short meta on that: he’s basically a Christ figure, dying for the sins of others). He respects and worships the old gods, swore a vow under the weirwood tree beyond the Wall, embraces the many lives (wargs, giants, skinchangers) beyond the Wall. The Night King doesn’t seem too concern about him, or too bothered to kill him. Jon is Lot.

Dany: unlike her ancestors, doesn’t bind her dragons with spells. Doesn’t think of her dragons as slaves. Understand that dragons aren’t something to be “owned” or “controlled”. Prays to the gods but blame the humans. Still mingle with magic: fairly respectfully, but it’s risky all the same. Has done some forbidden deeds before (resorting to blood magic to save Drogo). D is a complicated case. She has a grounded, “earth”, and very “human” self, symbolised by her dothraki side (think: food, sex, bodily functions, earth and grass, nature, senses: touch, smell, taste, sight, vision; as people of the “earth”, the dothraki also harbor an intense wariness toward anything remotely surnatural), but there’s an “Icarus” self to her as well. That being said, I think that D’s Icarus side met his end when Viserion – named after a man with an obvious megalomaniac complex – fell aflame from the sky.

Overall, I view D as Lot’s wife: at the critical moment, she might or might not look back, hence her mantra. (“If I look back, I am lost.”) Personally, I think she’ll be fine.

Arya: that’s a more complicated matter (see “some thoughts on Arya’s fate”)

Bran: has already been punished for catching sight of something he wasn’t supposed to see and was lucky enough to survive it. He’s good.

Sansa: might be the most allegorical/personified representation of Westeros as it stands. Sansa is purity sullied, has been traded and disputed over for the political games of bigger players (same as the woman being violated by 5 men in D’s vision), has now hardened and is responsible or involved (directly or indirectly) in the demise of three of the nastiest players out there: Joffrey, Ramsay and Littlefinger. She’s “earth purging herself”. The fate of Westeros (as a land) might possibly mirror her own, whatever that might mean.

“The Prince who was promised will bring the dawn”.

Dawn happens in the East, not the West. Sometime, I wonder if the “big twist” of asoiaf (the infamous “unpredictable” ending everyone seems to be talking about) might not be about Westeros returning to his/her primitive “sacred” state, which must be left untouched by humans, which means that survivors from Westeros would have to flee to Essos.

Thoughts?

“The Prince who was promised will bring the dawn”.

Dawn happens in the East, not the West. Sometime, I wonder if the “big twist” of asoiaf (the infamous “unpredictable” ending everyone seems to be talking about) might not be about Westeros returning to his/her primitive “sacred” state, which must be left untouched by humans, which means that survivors from Westeros would have to flee to Essos.

Thoughts?

trail.content_raw:
We can draw many parallels between the doom of Valyria and the destruction of Sodom. Moreover, we might also take bits and pieces of the myth to predict how asoiaf/got might end.

“In the Genesis account, God reveals to Abraham that Sodom and Gomorrah are to be destroyed for their grave sins (18:20). Abraham pleads for the lives of any righteous people living there, especially the lives of his nephew, Lot, and his family. God agrees to spare the cities if 10 righteous people can be found (18:23–32). Two angels are sent to Lot in Sodom but are met with a wicked mob who are then struck blind by the angelic guests (19:1–11). Finding only Lot and his family as righteous among the inhabitants, the angels warn Lot to quickly evacuate the city and to not look back. As they flee the destruction, Lot’s wife looks back upon the city and is turned into a pillar of salt (19:12–29).” (Source here)

To add some context (and details…), the city of Sodom was destroyed in a rain of fire and sulfur. The original “sin” of the inhabitants, except Lot and his family, would’ve been to deny hospitality to the 2 angels (disguised as men), then request of Lot to break guest rights by giving them the guests under his roof &protection. The men of Sodom apparently would’ve tried to break inside Lot’s house, then, only to be struck blind by the two angels.

Let’s remember two elements here: the punishment of Sodom, and the punishment of Lot’s wife.

Valyria is destroyed by fire and sulphur (from volcanic eruptions), counting only a handful of survivors (the Targaryen) who fled in time (like Lot and his family), and although we don’t really know why, or what caused the Doom, it’s almost 100% sure that the causes weren’t entirely “natural”. Sodom was destroyed because its inhabitants had angered God, and the reason why Valyria was destroyed probably isn’t so different: the valyrian and their dragonlords had angered the gods, somehow. Not necessarily because of their “depravities”, but rather because (and this is where I throw my first speculation) they mingled too much with forces not meant to be possessed and controlled by humans: blood magic, denaturing magical experiments, spells to bind dragons to their wills.

I use the term “gods” with a grain of salt: think “surnatural”, “mystical”, “surhuman”, “grander than men”. As a rule, in (all confounded) mythologies, men are neither supposed to defy gods (Prometheus, Icarus), nor can they look directly at gods, or god’s works in the making (Orpheus, Psyche, Lot’s wife). The fact that the ruins of Valyria are now oozing with “stone men” hence might have something to do with the “punishment” inflicted upon the lands: Lot’s wife was turned into a salt statue for looking back, and the “stone men” are something of statues themselves.  

Now flash forward to Westeros and their own upcoming doom: White Walkers.

Is it different from the situation in Valyria? Not really. The WW were also created as a response to men who were angering gods (cutting weirwood trees, waging war with the children of the forest, who probably personify the sacral aspect of nature). Dany’s vision of a woman, violated by 5 men/beasts all at once, in the HOTU, and the subsequent vision of the Red Wedding, with dead people, blood, limbs and heaps of food all piled up, all depict forms of “depravities” for which Sodom and Gomorrah were destroyed: rape and bestiality, gluttony, the breaking of guest rights. Cutting weirwood trees was profane in more ways than one: the red sap bleeding from the weirwood’s eyes act as a reminder to men not to look at gods directly. The Wall itself is an act of defiance against gods (humans shielding themselves from, and demonizing a more mystical, wild, archaic side of nature), and completely denatured the lands of Westeros (in “Clocks and dragons”, I argued that the Wall itself was causing the seasonal disbalance in Westeros). If the destruction of the Wall seemed nothing short of apocalyptic, it’s because it was: you’ve got gods-like figures (a dragon, an immortal man) coming in a “divine” rage for whoever dared to defy them. Theoretically speaking, men shouldn’t be able to fight that, let alone win. There lies the whole moral of the “leave to the gods what belongs to the gods” myths.

What does that say about the prospect of reinstituting peace in Westeros? At this point, that it’s unlikely.

What does it say about the (potential) fate of main characters? That’s another story. We’ll remember that not everyone was killed in the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah.

Jon: is obviously the messiah figure here (I’ve done a short meta on that: he’s basically a Christ figure, dying for the sins of others). He respects and worships the old gods, swore a vow under the weirwood tree beyond the Wall, embraces the many lives (wargs, giants, skinchangers) beyond the Wall. The Night King doesn’t seem too concern about him, or too bothered to kill him. Jon is Lot.

Dany: unlike her ancestors, doesn’t bind her dragons with spells. Doesn’t think of her dragons as slaves. Understand that dragons aren’t something to be “owned” or “controlled”. Prays to the gods but blame the humans. Still mingle with magic: fairly respectfully, but it’s risky all the same. Has done some forbidden deeds before (resorting to blood magic to save Drogo). D is a complicated case. She has a grounded, “earth”, and very “human” self, symbolised by her dothraki side (think: food, sex, bodily functions, earth and grass, nature, senses: touch, smell, taste, sight, vision; as people of the “earth”, the dothraki also harbor an intense wariness toward anything remotely surnatural), but there’s an “Icarus” self to her as well. That being said, I think that D’s Icarus side met his end when Viserion – named after a man with an obvious megalomaniac complex – fell aflame from the sky.

Overall, I view D as Lot’s wife: at the critical moment, she might or might not look back, hence her mantra. (“If I look back, I am lost.”) Personally, I think she’ll be fine.

Arya: that’s a more complicated matter (see “some thoughts on Arya’s fate”)

Bran: has already been punished for catching sight of something he wasn’t supposed to see and was lucky enough to survive it. He’s good.

Sansa: might be the most allegorical/personified representation of Westeros as it stands. Sansa is purity sullied, has been traded and disputed over for the political games of bigger players (same as the woman being violated by 5 men in D’s vision), has now hardened and is responsible or involved (directly or indirectly) in the demise of three of the nastiest players out there: Joffrey, Ramsay and Littlefinger. She’s “earth purging herself”. The fate of Westeros (as a land) might possibly mirror her own, whatever that might mean.

“The Prince who was promised will bring the dawn”.

Dawn happens in the East, not the West. Sometime, I wonder if the “big twist” of asoiaf (the infamous “unpredictable” ending everyone seems to be talking about) might not be about Westeros returning to his/her primitive “sacred” state, which must be left untouched by humans, which means that survivors from Westeros would have to flee to Essos.

Thoughts?
